awd_titl_txt: Separation of Colloidal Particles by Diffusiophoresis
awd_abstract_narration:
1702693:  Stone

Filtration is the most common method to remove particles from solution. We take it for granted that we can remove a wide range of particulate materials, such as dirt, bacteria, and viruses, from water by using filters that usually consist of porous materials, such as sand beds. Filtration is critical to obtaining safe drinking water and other liquids suitable for industrial processing. Nevertheless, instead of filtration there are technologies that use "fields", such as gravitational sedimentation, to remove particles and/or separate different kinds of particles. This project investigates how simple chemical gradients, even modest variations in salt concentration, can transport particles and achieve particle removal or separation by size without using filters or gravitational sedimentation. This approach is called diffusiophoresis, and it works for a wide range of particle sizes, is portable, can potentially be operated in field or resource-poor settings, and can be scaled to different sizes as may be required in a variety of applications. Importantly, diffusiophoresis may work for difficult separations of small particles using environmentally benign salts, when traditional filtration or sedimentation methods may be highly inefficient or even ineffective.

The objective of the research is to investigate diffusiophoretic-driven separation processes for a large class of particles, e.g. rigid particles of different size, shape and surface charge, droplets, and vesicles, in confined configurations, which typify a wide range of biological, chemical, and engineering materials and systems, e.g. porous media, structured surfaces and microdevices. Here "separation" is considered in its broadest sense, e.g. fractionation of different particles, isolation of particles from the fluid, and transport of particles to specific destinations. Diffusiophoresis refers to the migration of colloidal particles owing to osmotic pressure variations (chemiphoresis) and local electric fields generated by differences in diffusivities of cations and anions (electrophoresis). In the first aspect of this work these ideas are explored in confined geometries and separation of different particles is characterized. In particular, time-dependent diffusiophoretic strategies are described to achieve particle transport over long times. In the second aspect of this work, diffusiophoresis is created using interphase mass transfer, e.g. dissolution of CO2 gas. Consequently, approaches for removing particles in a membrane-less flow approach are described, and a new strategy for field flow fractionation is introduced. Experiments and modeling will be developed for a wide range of particles, particles of all types, rigid/soft particles, bacterial cells, vesicles. The research will achieve fundamental understanding of diffusiophoretic transport in confined spaces and improve macroscopic transport processes.

por.por_cntn:
Diffusiophoresis is a spontaneous migration of dispersed colloidal particles induced by concentration gradients of small molecules that are dissolved in a fluid. Concentration gradients of small molecules, e.g. common salts, which have diffusion coefficients about 1000 times larger than 1 micron diameter particles, can drive the motion of colloidal particles hundreds of times faster than by Brownian motion of the particles alone. The chemical gradient can also be created by dissolution of a soluble gas in a liquid. Although the equilibrium features associated with ions in solution have been well appreciated (and taught in textbooks) for over 100 years, the consequences of gradients - out-of-equilibrium phenomena - are less well appreciated and understood. In addition, we worked with and mentored postdocs, graduate students and undergraduates, including members of underrepresented groups, who coauthored some of our research papers. Finally, we continued our outreach efforts, including an annual (December) holiday science lecture given a total of four times in two cities, which introduces a new theme each year, and which has been given yearly since 2002.

We studied questions of diffusiophoresis, using experiments and mathematical models, from the standpoint of separation of particles of different types, e.g. rigid spheres of different chemistries, liquid drops, and bacteria. We have developed new experiments to achieve particle separation from a porous material and made significant progress using dissolved carbon dioxide to establish controllable chemical gradients to manipulate diffusiophoretic transport of particles and recently bacteria, which also implies the opportunity to mitigate biofilm formation on surfaces. Finally, we have made theoretical progress on several fronts that impact the larger field of electrokinetics.

During the course of this proposal we have:

1) Shown that particles can be separated from a flow (and so concentrated) by combining a fluid flow and a chemical gradient that drives diffusiophoretic transport opposite the flow direction

2) Shown how diffusiophoresis can arise in surfactant solutions, and in particular when such solutions are put in contact with water, which is important in all manners of detergency. Our results showing particle separation from a porous material effectively resolve a long-standing conundrum in detergency, i.e. how particles can be removed from region in a porous material where the effects of flow do not penetrate.

3) Used the phenomenon of diffusioosmosis to study surface-solute interactions via a novel microfluidic technique for measuring either the zeta potentials or the characteristic interaction length scales for surfaces exposed to electrolyte or non-electrolyte solutes, respectively.

4) Contributed a fundamental electrokinetic study of asymmetry in electrolyte valence in a study of the effects of asymmetry in electrolyte valence (i.e., non z:z electrolytes) on mean field theory of the electrical double layer. Thus, we determined the corresponding diffusiophoretic mobility.

5) Performed experiments for nonsymmetric valence of electrolytes, which were compared with the theory in item (4).

6) Systematically, and self consistently, accounted for the presence of a background electrolyte on the diffusion of a salt, which we studied using modeling, simulations and experiments.

7) Developed a new theoretical framework for the ionic layering near charged surfaces and our continuum model is in better agreement with molecular simulations than any existing theory.

8) Used modeling and experiments to account more consistently for the variation in ion concentration on the diffusiophoretic mobility so as to better account for the movement of colloidal particles through gradients of electrolyte (in particular, our work emphasizes that finite-double layer effects are crucial for dilute electrolytes whereas charge screening effects could be significant for concentrated electrolytes).

9) Documented diffusiophoresis of bacteria using chemical gradients created by dissolved CO2, which potentially may offer one route to mitigate biofilm formation on surfaces.
